title: Dashboard_1
text:
Data from datahub.io
Including population figures for countries, regions (e.g. Asia) and the world. Data comes originally from World Bank and has been converted into standard CSV. Data

Load Package and Data


library(broom)
library(tidyverse)
library(magrittr)
pop_data <- read.csv("population_csv.csv")


Show the world population by year


# Filter the Data
pop_all <- pop_data %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "WLD")

#Visualize
ggplot(pop_all, aes(x = Year, y = Value)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "World Population", x = "Year", y = "Population")





Show the US population growth per year by percentage


# Filter the Data
pop_USA <- pop_data %>%
    filter(Country.Code == "USA")%>%
    mutate(percentage = c(0,(diff(Value) /head(Value, -1))*100))


#Visualize
ggplot(pop_USA, aes(x = Year, y = percentage)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "World Population", x = "Year", y = "Population")

title: About
text:
Welcome to my first data science blog! It’s Jiajun Zhang here. And you can call me Acedia or Acky as well. If you find Jiajun is hard to pronounce.


Currently, I am enrolled as a student in the Master of Science in Information Management (MSIM) program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (UIUC).


This blog is a course project.


I consider myself a dedicated thinker who thrives on tackling intricate problems and developing innovative solutions to enhance model performance and interpretability. For leisure, I like to play card games like bridge.


Your interest and engagement are greatly appreciated.
